content.text:
# Draft:Star Wars: The Clone Wars season 1

| first_aired          =
| last_aired           =
| episode_list         = List of Star Wars: The Clone Wars episodes
}}
The first season of Star Wars: The Clone Wars, an American 3D action animated television series created by George Lucas, premiered on Cartoon Network on October 3, 2008, and concluded on March 20, 2009. The series was produced by Lucasfilm Animation and Lucasfilm Ltd., and it is preceded by the theatrical film of the same name. Set in the Star Wars universe between Episode II: Attack of the Clones and Episode III: Revenge of the Sith, the season follows Jedi Knights, Anakin Skywalker, Obi-Wan Kenobi, and the newly introduced Ahsoka Tano, along with clone troopers and other allies, as they battle Separatist forces during the galactic conflict known as the Clone Wars.
The series was developed to expand on the prequel trilogy’s characters and planets, with Lucas working alongside director Dave Filoni and writer Henry Gilroy. Before its television debut, several early episodes were compiled into a feature film of the same name released theatrically in August 2008. The first episodes, "Ambush," premiered on Cartoon Network to nearly four million viewers, becoming the network's most-watched series debut at the time. While some later episodes saw a dip in ratings, the season finale, "Hostage Crisis," attracted around three million viewers.
The series received mixed reviews, with critics praising the animation style and action sequences, but noting uneven writing and themes. The episode “Lair of Grievous” won a Golden Reel Award for sound editing, and composer Kevin Kiner received an Annie Award nomination for his musical work on the show.  The full season was released on DVD and Blu-ray in November 2009. It later became available for streaming on ITunes, Amazon and Disney+. Due to the show popularity, it was preserved as part of the franchise canon following Disney’s acquisition of Lucasfilm in 2012.
Development
Concept and creation
George Lucas conceived an animated Star Wars series during the production of Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith (2005), aiming to flesh out the adventures of Jedi Knights Obi-Wan Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker, as well as explore the characters and planets introduced in the prequel trilogy. Despite initially planning to end the story with Episode III, he decided to move forward with an in-house animated series.
In August 2005, Lucas confirmed that two Star Wars-themed television projects were underway: an animated series and a live-action series. In February 2006, Steve Sansweet detailed that the animated series would use CG, 3-dimensional animation, similar to Toy Story, and would be set during the Clone Wars period between the prequels. In March 2007, at the William S. Paley Television Festival, Lucas confirmed that the series would be 3D animated and consist of 100 episodes, describing it as a "test" for a larger project. He said it would capture the ambiance of the live-action films and push the boundaries of television animation.
Lucas explained that the tone would vary, with some episodes being more comedic, though it would avoid "Saturday morning" humor. The series would be episodic rather than serialized, allowing it to explore stories beyond the central Skywalker narrative. He teased episodes focused on side characters like the Clone Troopers, including one centered entirely on Jedi Kit Fisto, a minor character from the prequel films. At the time, Lucas noted his team was producing the first 100 episodes without a network deal, though he was confident one would be secured.
In late August of that year, Catherine Winder described the series as being produced in a way "akin to an anthology series", she explained, this format allows each 22-minute episode to stand on its own, enabling viewers to jump in at any point and quickly get oriented. While some episodes are action-driven, many focus on personal, character-based stories, offering deeper insight into both familiar and lesser-known characters from the Star Wars universe and it follows the "goal and spirit" of Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope (1977).
Lucas made the unusual decision to wait until nearly the end of production on the first season before pitching the series to television networks in early 2007. Initially, none showed interest. Fox Broadcasting Company, which distributed the prequel films, declined. Cartoon Network, which had previously aired Star Wars: Clone Wars (2003–2005), was also unenthusiastic. However, interest shifted after Lucas chose to release a theatrical film of the same name. Around the same time, Stuart Snyder, president of Cartoon Network flew to San Francisco to screen several episodes, calling it a "game-changing" series. The film, released in August 2008, combined several episodes as a prelude to the series. Its main story came from a three-episode arc, "Castle of Deception", "Castle of Doom" and "Castle of Salvation", while the opening sequence, "The New Padawan", introduced Ahsoka Tano.
Production
Filoni initially proposed a series centered on a group of recurring characters traveling aboard a spaceship similar to the Millennium Falcon, including a Jedi apprentice named Ashla, and her Jedi Master.|name=Rebels|group=note}} Working with Henry Gilroy, Filoni discussed these early ideas and introduced characters like Rotta and his father, Ziro, aiming to create a story that wouldn’t interfere with existing continuity, featuring only occasional appearances by film characters like Obi-Wan Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker. However, Lucas rejected this approach, insisting the series focus on film characters. As a result, Ashla was reimagined as Ahsoka, Anakin's Padawan, and characters like Rotta and Ziro were integrated into the film.
Although the concept of a young female Padawan was originally meant for Obi-Wan, Lucas reassigned her to Anakin to break their repetitive dynamic and emphasize his growth from apprentice to equal. Filoni and Gilroy developed Ahsoka as a blend of "Anakin’s brashness and Obi-Wan’s measured judgment," reflecting the shift from Republic to Empire. Filoni explained, "Ahsoka is between them, looking back at what was, looking forward to what might be". Lucas also intended Ahsoka to help mature Anakin, who was portrayed as a "wild child" with a strained relationship with Obi-Wan after Attack of the Clones. Drawing from his experience as a father, Lucas felt a teenage girl would be just as challenging for Anakin to mentor as a boy.
The season also introduced two new types of droids: the tactical droid and the commando droid. The first one was developed to present a more efficient villain, with its voice partially inspired by the robot Lucifer from the 1978 Battlestar Galactica series. The second one, a hybrid of the standard and super battle droids, was designed with a human-like silhouette and posed a greater threat to clone soldiers and Jedi due to its superior intelligence and speed.
Each episode begins with a moral theme, called "The Jedi cookie", followed by a brief recap. The stories emphasize "cause and effect," aiming to teach valuable lessons through characters' choices. Winder noted the show is crafted for a family audience, offering meaningful content. The first episode, "Ambush", reintroduced Yoda with an exaggerated, stylized appearance with the trooper, contrasting with his serious portrayal in the prequel films. The episode features a poignant scene between Yoda and his troopers, echoing Luke Skywalker's training on Dagobah in Star Wars: Episode V – The Empire Strikes Back (1980), where the Jedi eases their self-doubts by praising their traits. Despite the negative reception of Jar Jar Binks in the prequels, he appears in the episode "Bombad Jedi", as Lucas wanted him during the war period. The episode is framed as a fairy tale, with Padmé as the princess in distress, C-3PO as the servant, and the sea monster Kwazel Maw replacing a dragon. The episode "Jedi Crash" further develops Aayla Secura, who first appeared in Star Wars: Republic comics and briefly in the prequels. For Filoni, it was an opportunity to portray her as Ahsoka’s older sister and was initially planned to have a rough voice and American accent, but a French accent was chosen instead, helping to define her personality.
The episode arc of "Defenders of Peace", inspired by Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai (1954), introduces a pacifist perspective through the Lurmen people. The following episode, "Trespass", draws inspiration from the American frontier conquest, where pioneers are threatened by indigenous people superior in numbers. The final arc, consisting of episodes 19-21 ("Storm Over Ryloth", "Innocents of Ryloth" and "Liberty on Ryloth"), is set on the planet Ryloth and depicts the consequences of war. Originally, in the first episode of the arc, Anakin was meant to participate in the battle between the Republic and the Separatists over Ryloth. However, Lucas suggested leaving Anakin on the cruiser’s bridge to help build his confidence in Ahsoka.
Soundtracks
The sound design was created by Ben Burtt, with a team from Skywalker Sound: David Acord, Juan Peralta, and Matthew Wood. All three had previously worked on the prequel films, ensuring it sounds like Star Wars. Peralta notes, "The entire crew considers each episode a mini-feature, and we are used to doing film-quality work". Acord creates new sounds using "real-world items", like "vibrating back massagers on a vinyl record", for the Malevolence arc (episodes 2–3). Wood edits the sounds together, including the dialogue, while Peralta mixes the sound with the music.
Cast and characters
Main
* Matt Lanter as Anakin Skywalker: A Jedi Knight and leader of Republic forces during the Clone Wars.
* Ashley Eckstein as Ahsoka Tano: Anakin Skywalker's young and skilled Padawan.
* James Arnold Taylor as:
** Obi-Wan Kenobi: A wise and experienced Jedi Master.
** Plo Koon: A calm and respected Jedi Master.
** Barb Mentir, Tae Boon, and LEP-86C8: Republic officer, Twi'lek character, and rabbit-like service droid.
* Dee Bradley Baker as:
** Clone Troopers: Soldiers cloned from Jango Fett, including Captain Rex and Commander Cody.
** Onaconda Farr: Rodian senator and ally of the Republic.
** Robonino: Fish-like bounty hunter.
* Matthew Wood as:
** Battle Droids: Robotic soldiers of the Separatist Alliance.
** General Grievous: Ruthless cyborg general.
** Wat Tambor: Techno Union foreman and Separatist leader.
* Tom Kane as:
** Narrator
** Yoda: Wise Jedi Grand Master.
** Admiral Wullf Yularen: Seasoned Republic naval officer.
Recurring
* Nika Futterman as Asajj Ventress: Dark assassin and apprentice of Count Dooku.
* Ian Abercrombie as Palpatine / Darth Sidious: Supreme Chancellor and secret Sith Lord.
* Corey Burton as:
** Count Dooku / Darth Tyranus: Leader of the Separatists.
** Senator Kharrus and Shahan Alama: Gran senator and Weequay bounty hunter.
** Mar Tuuk: Neimoidian tactical officer.
** Ziro the Hutt: Hutt crime lord.
* Anthony Daniels as C-3PO: Protocol droid fluent in millions of languages.
* R2-D2: Loyal astromech droid companion to Anakin Skywalker.
* Catherine Taber as:
** Padmé Amidala: Senator of Naboo and Anakin's secret wife.
** Angel of Iego and Numa: Mythical being and Twi'lek orphan.
* Ahmed Best as Jar Jar Binks: Gungan diplomat.
* Terrence C. Carson as Mace Windu: Senior Jedi Council member.
Guest stars
* Brian George as:
** King Katuunko: Toydarian ruler.
** Chairman Chi Cho: Pantoran leader.
* Gwendoline Yeo as:
** Nala Se: Kaminoan scientist.
** Peppi Bow: Twi'lek resistance fighter.
* Olivia d'Abo as Luminara Unduli: Jedi Master.
* Ron Perlman as Gha Nachkt: Trandoshan scavenger.
* Tom Kenny as:
** Silood: Weequay pirate.
** Nute Gunray: Trade Federation viceroy.
** Nahdar Vebb: Mon Calamari Jedi Knight.
* James Marsters as Captain Faro Argyus: Senate Guard officer.
* Phil LaMarr as:
** Kit Fisto: Nautolan Jedi Master.
** Amit Noloff and Senator Philo: Technician and Republic senator.
** Orn Free Taa: Twi'lek senator of Ryloth.
** Bail Organa: Senator of Alderaan.
* Jennifer Hale as:
** Aayla Secura: Twi'lek Jedi Master.
** Senator Riyo Chuchi: Pantoran senator.
* George Coe as Tee Watt Kaa: Lurmen village leader.
* Alec Medlock as Wag Too: Lurmen youth and healer.
* George Takei as Lok Durd: Neimoidian general.
* James C. Mathis III as Captain Gregar Typho: Naboo security chief.
* Jameelah McMillan as Queen Neeyutnee: Queen of Naboo.
* Michael York as Dr. Nuvo Vindi: Separatist bioweapons expert.
* David Acord as EV-A4-D and Zignat: Medical droid and Twi'lek arms dealer.
* David Kaufman as Jaybo Hood: Human tech prodigy.
* Greg Ellis as Turk Falso: Weequay pirate lieutenant.
* Jim Cummings as Hondo Ohnaka: Pirate leader of the Ohnaka gang.
* Jaime King as Aurra Sing: Force-sensitive bounty hunter.
* Robin Atkin Downes as Cham Syndulla: Twi'lek freedom fighter.
Broadcast and ratings
Stuart Snyder, president of Cartoon Network, built an "action-adventure block" around the series, aligns with the network’s core audience. Snyder views the series as a "mini movie" with broad appeal, engaging kids, particularly boys aged 6 to 14, as well as their parents who grew up with the franchise. On October 3, 2008, Cartoon Network premiered a one-hour presentation of the first two episodes of Star Wars: The Clone Wars, beginning with "Ambush," at 9 p.m. in the U.S., becoming Cartoon Network’s most-watched series debut with total of 3.96 million viewers.}}
The premiere dominated its time slot across all major kids' networks, delivering the highest ratings ever for a Cartoon Network original series debut. It attracted 1.8 million viewers aged 2–11, 1.4 million aged 6–11, and 1.2 million viewers aged 9–14. Compared to the same time slot in 2007, these numbers marked huge increases: 125% for ages 2–11, 120% for 6–11, and 91% for 9–14. Boys, in particular, drove the surge, with viewership jumping by roughly 150% across all demographics.
Despite its strong start, the rest of the episodes experienced a dip, hitting a low point with episode nine, "Cloak of Darkness," which drew just 1.95 million viewers. However, the following episodes such as "Blue Shadow Virus" attracted 2.94 million viewers, and "Liberty on Ryloth” garnered 3.01 million. The season finale, "Hostage Crisis," aired on March 20, 2009, and marked a high point with 3.29 million viewers.
Episodes
| ProdCode        = 1.08
| ShortSummary    = Jedi Master Yoda must face off against Count Dooku's dreaded assassin Asajj Ventress and her massive droid army to prove the Jedi are strong enough to protect a strategic planet and forge a treaty for the Republic. Ventress fails against Yoda, so Dooku tells Ventress to kill the king of the planet, who wants to sign the treaty with the Republic. Yoda protects the king from Ventress, who then flees.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.07
| ShortSummary    = An attack by a devastating new Separatist weapon—the powerful starship Malevolence—leaves Jedi Master Plo Koon and his clone troopers struggling to survive until Anakin and Ahsoka can find them.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.09
| ShortSummary    = With the help of his Padawan, Ahsoka, and Jedi Master Plo Koon, Anakin uses new long-range Y-wing bombers to lead a bold strike on General Grievous's warship, the Malevolence, and its destructive weapon.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.11
| ShortSummary    = Padmé Amidala and C-3PO are taken hostage by General Grievous, leaving Anakin and Obi-Wan to save the senator and complete the destruction of the Malevolence.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.14
| ShortSummary    = Alone on a distant outpost, clone officers Rex and Cody must inspire their rookie unit to believe in themselves to stave off a droid commando invasion.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.02
| ShortSummary    = R2-D2 is lost during a fierce space battle—and Anakin must find him before the Separatists discover the Jedi military secrets locked in his memory banks.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.06
| ShortSummary    = Anakin, Ahsoka, and replacement droid R3-S6 embark on a dual rescue/sabotage mission when they discover that R2-D2 is being held at General Grievous's secret enemy listening post, Skytop Station.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.05
| ShortSummary    = On a diplomatic mission to the planet Rodia, Padmé discovers that her old friend and fellow Republic senator Onaconda Farr has allied his planet with the Separatists. In exchange for food and resources for his people, Onaconda captures Padmé and promises to deliver her to Nute Gunray. Sensing that Padmé is in trouble, Jar Jar Binks disguises himself as a Jedi and, with the help of , courageously fights to rescue his friend and fellow senator.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.10
| ShortSummary    = Ahsoka and Jedi Master Luminara Unduli escort the captured notorious Separatist leader Nute Gunray to Coruscant so he can stand trial for his crimes. However, they are unaware that Count Dooku has sent his assassin, Asajj Ventress, to free their captive. With the help of Senate Commandos, the Jedi have to thwart Ventress's efforts to free their prisoner, despite the traitorous plans of Senate Guard Captain Argyus.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.12
| ShortSummary    = Jedi Master Kit Fisto and his former Padawan, the Mon Calamari Jedi Nahdar Vebb, track escaped prisoner Nute Gunray to a remote world. Following Nute into a mysterious den filled with strange creatures, weapons, and war-time artifacts, the Jedi discover that it is the trap-laden lair of General Grievous. Learning that Count Dooku has led the Jedi there in order to punish Grievous for his recent failures, the general is determined to prove his abilities and destroy the Jedi. Kit and Nahdar, along with a contingent of clones, must now fight their way past Grievous and his caretaker droid  to avoid being caught in Grievous's evil clutches forever.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.16
| ShortSummary    = During their own attempt to kidnap Dooku, Anakin and Obi-Wan discover that the Sith lord has already been captured by pirates. Hondo Ohnaka and his gang of pirates hold Dooku captive in their den on Florrum, and hold him for ransom. It is up to Anakin and Obi-Wan to see if the offer is too good to be true.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.20
| ShortSummary    = Anakin and Obi-Wan have been duped and are being held for ransom, along with Count Dooku, by the pirate chief Hondo Ohnaka and his second-in-command, Turk Falso. While Anakin, Obi-Wan, and Dooku unsuccessfully attempt to escape, the Republic sends the ransom via a special envoy, including Representative Jar Jar Binks. When Falso tries to steal the ransom from his boss by shooting down the shuttle, the only survivors are a squad of clones and Jar Jar, who, as the most senior officer alive, has to take charge of the mission. It becomes a race against time as Jar Jar rushes to deliver the ransom to take custody of Dooku and save the Jedi.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.22
| ShortSummary    = Anakin and Ahsoka arrive at a pitched sky battle to help besieged Jedi General Aayla Secura. Anakin is gravely injured in the fight. Aayla and Ahsoka, along with the now-wounded Anakin, Rex, and the surviving clones, crash land on the uncharted grass-covered planet Maridun. Forced to leave Anakin behind in order to save him, Aayla teaches Ahsoka why the Jedi have no personal attachments. They make their way to a Lurmen village. Their ruler, Tee Watt Kaa, explains that they are pacifists in this war and not aligned with either side. Hesitant to have anything to do with the Jedi, Kaa agrees to help save Anakin's life.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.24
| ShortSummary    = Tee Watt Kaa refuses to shelter the Jedi from arriving Separatist forces, fearing that such an action would unnecessarily bring his neutral people into the war. Ahsoka, Aayla, the wounded Anakin, and the rest of the clones respect their wishes as they do not want to jeopardize the village with their presence, so they have to retreat into the wilds of the planet. Separatist Neimoidian General Lok Durd arrives to test a devastating weapon, which they plan to use on the Lurmen. Ultimately, the villagers have to decide whether they will surrender to the Separatists or fight with the Jedi to defend their village.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.25
| ShortSummary    = Arriving on the desolate ice world of Orto Plutonia, Anakin and Obi-Wan investigate the disappearance of a clone security force stationed on a remote outpost. The Jedi, accompanied by Senator Riyo Chuchi and Chairman Cho of the nearby moon of Pantora, soon discover their clone troopers were attacked by a tribe of furry natives known as the Talz. Fierce beast-riding warriors, the Talz are very territorial and only want to be left alone. The Jedi manage to negotiate peace with the Talz chieftain, Thi-Sen, when greedy Chairman Cho breaks it by insisting that the planet and the Talz are under his power. The resulting conflict escalates into war between the clones and the Talz, with the Jedi caught in the middle.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 2.01
| ShortSummary    = Anakin and Obi-Wan lead Republic forces in an attempt to defeat the droid armies and free the planet of Christophsis from the Separatist siege. When the Republic is ambushed and forced to retreat, it becomes clear that someone in their midst has set them up. The Jedi believe this infiltration is a Sith-backed operation and go behind enemy lines to investigate. Meanwhile, Captain Rex and Commander Cody set out to uncover the traitor amongst them.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.26
| ShortSummary    = The Republic discovers a Separatist bio-weapon lab hidden on the planet of Naboo. Rather than wait for help, Padmé explores the lab with Jar Jar. Anakin, Ahsoka, Rex, and Obi-Wan arrive and follow after her. They find that the Senator is being held captive by the sinister Dr. Nuvo Vindi. The mad scientist has been developing a lethal virus for the Separatists. Vindi threatens to set off a bomb and release the virus.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 2.02
| ShortSummary    = Even though the lab has been shut down, Dr. Vindi manages to activate the dreaded Blue Shadow Virus, infecting Ahsoka, Padmé, and many clone troopers. The plague is fatal within 48 hours. Anakin and Obi-Wan must travel to the mysterious planet Iego to secure the only known antidote to the sickness. They arrive to find its population living in fear of a mysterious force that has been killing anything that tries to leave their world. With the help of Jaybo Hood, a clever Iegoan boy, Anakin and Obi-Wan must solve the planet's mystery before they can leave, and before everyone infected with the Separatist virus dies.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.15
| ShortSummary    = Ryloth, home world of the Twi'lek people, has been subjected to military occupation by the droid army of the Separatists and surrounded by a blockade of Trade Federation battleships. While launching a surprise attack against the blockade, Ahsoka disobeys Anakin's orders and ends up losing most of her squadron. Even though she is emotionally rocked by this failure, Anakin helps her learn to persevere, placing her in charge of another risky attack.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.17
| ShortSummary    = With the space blockade around Ryloth destroyed, Obi-Wan must lead a small clone force into a droid-occupied town to sabotage their anti-aircraft guns. Obi-Wan's mission is complicated when he learns the town's inhabitants are being used as living shields. A pair of clones in his platoon forges an unlikely friendship with a refugee Twi'lek girl, Numa, who has been orphaned by the war. Through their relationship with her, the clones begin to understand the real cost of the war.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 1.19
| ShortSummary    = The battle for Ryloth rages as the Republic attempts to drive off the occupying droid army led by Techno Union foreman Wat Tambor. With his forces stretched thin, Mace Windu must convince Twi'lek freedom fighter Cham Syndulla to help him save the capital city from the droids' destruction. Initially, the Twi'lek hero is hesitant to aid Mace, but ultimately he realizes that the Jedi can be trusted and joins with him to liberate the city—and ultimately the planet—in the climactic battle.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
| ProdCode        = 2.04
| ShortSummary    = In an attempt to force the release of the crime lord Ziro the Hutt from prison, bounty hunters seize control of the Senate Building and hold members of the Senate hostage. Cad Bane, the leader of the operation, with the help of bounty hunter Aurra Sing, issues his demands to Chancellor Palpatine, who has no choice but to meet his request. Unbeknownst to the hunters, Anakin is loose in the Senate building.
| LineColor       = B11010
}}
}}
Continuity
The announcement of the animated feature film and the series sparked debate over their place in the Star Wars canon. The debate centered on their timeline and conflicts with existing continuity. Writer Henry Gilroy explained that Lucasfilm followed a tiered canon system, and to accommodate the series, continuity expert Leland Chee introduced "T-canon," a new tier specifically for television content.
In 2012, Disney acquired Lucasfilm and overhauled the Star Wars canon. To create a more consistent storyline, nearly all pre-2014 content, except the six original films was rebranded as Star Wars Legends, a separate timeline where the sequel trilogy does not exist. According to IGN, The Clone Wars was one of the few pre-Disney projects retained in the official canon, due to its popularity and narrative significance.
Reception
The season was better received than the theatrical film, due in part to the length of the episodes allowing for more action and suspense and a shift towards a more adult audience than the feature film. Barry Garron of The Hollywood Reporter noted its "as close to 3-D as you can without wearing those dorky glasses," praising its ability to "reflect the style, attitude, ideals and spirit of the six Star Wars films." Chicago Tribune noted the series' better pacing compared to the prequel films, but criticized the series' worlds as being bland and lifeless despite the " technically impressive" 3D animation.
Similarly, Den of Geek called the animation "fluid and impressive," particularly in lightsaber duels and space battles. However, Martin Hoyle of the Financial Times criticized the character designs as "rehashed Thunderbirds with a dash of Japanese anime," finding the humans unnervingly artificial.
Critics were divided on the show's writing. Eric Goldman of IGN acknowledged its "taut and involving" episodes like "Rookies," which showcased the Clone Troopers' perspectives, but lamented the "wacky, silly" Battle Droids and Jar Jar Binks' return as low points. Tony Patterson od Slate dismissed the series as "pinball on a cosmic scale," arguing it prioritized sensation over substance, with Patterson calling it "expendable" storytelling. Conversely, SciFiNow noted a "clear rise in quality" as the season progressed, praising its darker themes and character development for the Clone Troopers.
While some critics, like Rafe Telsch of CinemaBlend, declared the series a "horrific blight" that marked the death of Star Wars for older fans, others saw merit in its appeal to younger audiences with Robert Lloyd of the Los Angeles Times argued the shift to animation was a "natural outcome" of Lucas' digital-focused filmmaking, though he found Ahsoka Tano's character polarizing. Over time, the series gained a cult following, with Den of Geek noting its "surprisingly effective character moments" and deeper exploration of the Clone Troopers' humanity.
At the 2009 Golden Reel Awards, episode “Lair of Grievous” won the award for Best Sound Editing in Television Animation. The sound editing was led by Matthew Wood and David Acord. The award recognized the sound effects, foley, dialogue, and ADR for the animated television series. Later that year, Kevin Kiner received a nomination for his musical work on the show, particularly for the episode "Rising Malevolence," at Annie Awards for Music in a Television Production. Additionally, the series scoured a nomination for Best Animated Film and Saturn Award for Best Network Television Series at the 2009 Saturn Awards.
Media
of the complete season in the United States.]]
The series was first made available for streaming on iTunes the day after each episode aired, beginning Saturday, October 4, 2008. Episodes were also released a week later on the Cartoon Network and Star Wars websites. Lucasfilm also released a free 30-minute behind-the-scenes special on iTunes. Later, the series became available on Amazon and Disney+.
The first home media  release came in March 2009 with A Galaxy Divided, a DVD featuring the first four episodes. The Walmart edition featured episode six as a bonus. In Septembe of that year, Clone Commandos, was released with episodes 5 and 19–21. The full season was then released on DVD and Blu-ray in November 2009.
